cards.name: Action items
Process documentation
Github
Personnel, roles, schedules
Labor category mapping doc
Price quote sheet
Criteria template

cards.desc: https://docs.google.com/a/civicactions.com/forms/d/10gQ0TzzjZD68y-rg5jmAmLTslVoeeu9tCr9lidOgBz0/viewform
cards.name: Compliance review checklist
Be useful to FDA data users
Be cool
used at least five modern and open-source technologies, regardless of architectural layer (frontend, backend etc)

cards.desc:
Rob: Adverse drug events database, largest and most recently made available. For 20 years FDA has recorded every adverse reaction to a drug. Valuable to many people - drug producers (pro vs con), healthcare advocates (con vs pro), researchers (discovering interactions).

API data structure is moderately complex. Not very approachable for consumers. Developed by presidential IT fellow.

JSON based API - example:
Date: ...
Person (no name)
Outcome:
Event:
Where:
Drug:

Some fields are structured, some are free text. Some other tables to detail/embellish standardized fields (Drugs etc).
cards.name: Uses FDA data

cards.desc: assigned one leader, gave that person authority and responsibility, and held that person accountable for the quality of the prototype submitted
cards.name: One leader
Clearly valuable to consumers (either doctors or consumers), ideally have an easy step-through or video showing how to use.

cards.desc: assembled a multidisciplinary and collaborative team including a minimum of 5 labor categories from the Development Pool labor categories to design and develop the prototype
cards.name: Multidisciplinary Team

cards.desc: understand what people need, by including people in the prototype development and design process
cards.name: Include "people" in the process

cards.desc: used at least three "human-centered design" techniques or tools
cards.name: At least 3 human centered design techniques

cards.desc: created or used a design style guide and/or a pattern library
cards.name: Uses style guide
Perform usability tests with people

cards.desc: used an iterative approach, where feedback informed subsequent work or versions of the prototype
cards.name: Iterative approach
Multi-device, responsive

cards.desc: deployed the prototype on an Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) or Platform as a Service (PaaS) provider, and indicated which provider they used
cards.name: Iaas or PaaS
Write unit tests for code

cards.desc: set up or used a continuous integration system to automate the running of tests and continuously deployed their code to their IaaS or PaaS provider
cards.name: Continuous integration; automated testing
Set up or use configuration management
Set up or use continuous monitoring
Software deployed in container

cards.desc: Make use of a API, by either consuming or providing one RESTfully.
cards.name: API

cards.desc: provided sufficient documentation to install and run their prototype on another machine
cards.name: Installation documentation

cards.desc: prototype and underlying platforms used to create and run the prototype are openly licensed and free of charge
cards.name: Open license
1. Understand what people need

cards.desc: We need to understand the different ways people will interact with our services, including the actions they take online, through a mobile application, on a phone, or in person. Every encounter — whether it's online or offline — should move the user closer towards their goal.
cards.name: 2. Address the whole experience, from start to finish

cards.desc: Using a government service shouldn’t be stressful, confusing, or daunting. It’s our job to build services that are simple and intuitive enough that users succeed the first time, unaided.
cards.name: 3. Make it simple and intuitive

cards.desc: We should use an incremental, fast-paced style of software development to reduce the risk of failure. We want to get working software into users’ hands as early as possible to give the design and development team opportunities to adjust based on user feedback about the service. A critical capability is being able to automatically test and deploy the service so that new features can be added often and be put into production easily.
cards.name: 4. Build the service using agile and iterative practices

cards.desc:
To improve our chances of success when contracting out development work, we need to work with experienced budgeting and contracting officers. In cases where we use third parties to help build a service, a well-defined contract can facilitate good development practices like conducting a research and prototyping phase, refining product requirements as the service is built, evaluating open source alternatives, ensuring frequent delivery milestones, and allowing the flexibility to purchase cloud computing resources.

The TechFAR Handbook provides a detailed explanation of the flexibilities in the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) that can help agencies implement this play.
cards.name: 5. Structure budgets and contracts to support delivery

cards.desc: There must be a single product owner who has the authority and responsibility to assign tasks and work elements; make business, product, and technical decisions; and be accountable for the success or failure of the overall service. This product owner is ultimately responsible for how well the service meets needs of its users, which is how a service should be evaluated. The product owner is responsible for ensuring that features are built and managing the feature and bug backlogs.
cards.name: 6. Assign one leader and hold that person accountable

cards.desc: We need talented people working in government who have experience creating modern digital services. This includes bringing in seasoned product managers, engineers, and designers. When outside help is needed, our teams should work with contracting officers who understand how to evaluate third-party technical competency so our teams can be paired with contractors who are good at both building and delivering effective digital services. The makeup and experience requirements of the team will vary depending on the scope of the project.
cards.name: 7. Bring in experienced teams

cards.desc: The technology decisions we make need to enable development teams to work efficiently and enable services to scale easily and cost-effectively. Our choices for hosting infrastructure, databases, software frameworks, programming languages and the rest of the technology stack should seek to avoid vendor lock-in and match what successful modern consumer and enterprise software companies would choose today. In particular, digital services teams should consider using open source, cloud-based, and commodity solutions across the technology stack, because of their widespread adoption and support by successful consumer and enterprise technology companies in the private sector.
cards.name: 8. Choose a modern technology stack

cards.desc: Our services should be deployed on flexible infrastructure, where resources can be provisioned in real-time to meet spikes traffic and user demand. Our digital services are crippled when we host them in data centers that market themselves as “cloud hosting” but require us to manage and maintain hardware directly. This outdated practice wastes time, weakens our disaster recovery plans, and results in significantly higher costs.
cards.name: 9. Deploy in a flexible hosting environment

cards.desc: Today, developers write automated scripts that can verify thousands of scenarios in minutes and then deploy updated code into production environments multiple times a day. They use automated performance tests which simulate surges in traffic to identify performance bottlenecks. While manual tests and quality assurance are still necessary, automated tests provide consistent and reliable protection against unintentional regressions, and make it possible for developers to confidently release frequent updates to the service.
cards.name: 10. Automate testing and deployments

cards.desc: Our digital services have to protect sensitive information and keep systems secure. This is typically a process of continuous review and improvement which should be built into the development and maintenance of the service. At the start of designing a new service or feature, the team lead should engage the appropriate privacy, security, and legal officer(s) to discuss the type of information collected, how it should be secured, how long it is kept, and how it may be used and shared. The sustained engagement of a privacy specialist helps ensure that personal data is properly managed. In addition, a key process to building a secure service is comprehensively testing and certifying the components in each layer of the technology stack for security vulnerabilities, and then to re-use these same pre-certified components for multiple services.The following checklist provides a starting point, but teams should work closely with their privacy specialist and security engineer to meet the needs of the specific service.
cards.name: 11. Manage security and privacy through reusable processes

cards.desc: At every stage of a project, we should measure how well our service is working for our users. This includes measuring how well a system performs and how people are interacting with it in real-time. Our teams and agency leadership should carefully watch these metrics to find issues and identify which bug fixes and improvements should be prioritized. Along with monitoring tools, a feedback mechanism should be in place for people to report issues directly.
cards.name: 12. Use data to drive decisions

cards.desc: When we collaborate in the open and publish our data publicly, we can improve Government together. By building services more openly and publishing open data, we simplify the public’s access to government services and information, allow the public to contribute easily, and enable reuse by entrepreneurs, nonprofits, other agencies, and the public.
cards.name: 13. Default to open
Enter symptom, and medications taking, to show which medication are known to cause symptom.

Grandparent Guardian: Enter your dependents medicines and review all possible adverse events aggregated for the set of medicines. See this as a function of time vs number of people prescribed those meds. Tie in to other information about those meds. Focus on drug interaction possibilities. This is a side affect management system.
An app that a doctor (or patient) could use prior to prescribing multiple drugs to validate if there are adverse effects with each other.
Citizen science to find potential correlations etc
Build a visual map of all drug events, and be able to replay them across time. Show a blinking map of your city to show the events.
Prescription tool for adults caring for elderly parents
Food alert similar to CityGram
Community like stack exchange
Look up reactions to drugs I am taking
Walled-garden community in which only professionals can play --- we can make our github repo workable for that purpose.  Using Drupal and virtualization should be possible.
User takes a picture with their mobile phone (or enters pill identifying information) to quickly retrieve the adverse effects.
look-ahead type search, where I start typing "hyper..." and it automatically starts showing me medications prescribed for hypertension and hyperactivity.  Gogglize the database.
Use the UNII to find a way to search for gluten-free, vegan, etc. medicines, and look for reactions based on incredients rather than drug.
Create an adverse alert system in which you customize the drugs of interest to you, and receive alerts on conditions.
Find people whose loved ones are taking a similar profile to your meds.

cards.desc:
As a user I am having a particular symptom, and I want to consider what drug (or drugs) might be causing that symptom

Taking multiple drugs and trying to figure out the interactions between those

"Want to visualize the impact of taking multiple drugs and their possible adverse events".

"Which drug is most likely causing an adverse effect."
	
I am a patient/or guardian taking multiple medications and don't which one to start looking at.
cards.name: Problem statement
An advanced practice nurse/prescriber specialty family practice and clinical education.  I use this site to determine clearance for medical devices (CLIA waived), product safety, etc.
Justice advocate seeking to demonstrate that most drug testing being done on white males leads to more side effects for women and minority genetic groups.
Advocate of natural healing seeking to emphasize danger of prescribed drugs over natural remedies.
Adult caring for elderly parent(s) and managing their prescriptions.

I still don't quite know how one discovers the various vocablulaires in the system. I think we as a team need to know how to get the list of all known adverse events, and the list of all known drugs, etc.
Does the database include all the drugs that a person is taking when a reaction is reported? - Ethan answered: Yes it Does!
How can we see all the fields? Seems like what's available will influence what we may do.

How can we correlate a drug with the number of times it is likely to be used? Can we find out that Tylenol is used 100M times with 1K serious affects, but something else is used 10K times with 10 serious effects, which is actually 10 times more likely to cause an effect?
"As a <user> I want to <do somthing> so that <achieve objective/motivation>"
As a consumer, I want to enter my medicines and my affects and see how often others have experienced them to give me peace of mind.

As a person who is taking multiple drugs and is having an adverse affect, I would like to see a visualization of the adverse events associated with my drug regime to understand and perhaps decrease them.
As a consumer, I want to be able to easily enter my drug regime with typeahead based on multiple names to get the benefits of the system.

As a caregiver, I am caring for someone and I know what drugs they take, but they are having side effects and I want to understand how they may be related to the drugs they are taking and consider the impact of changes to there regime.
As a consumer, I want to store and consider multiple drug regimes to be able to compare them.
As a consumer, I want to enter my ailments in the language of the database so that I can easily get the benefits of the system.
As a consumer, I want to understand the benefits that your system offers to that i can decide whether or not to use it.
As a consumer, I want to test your system without giving any personal information, and then later associate my searches with my identity if I choose to.
As a caregiver, I want my parent to enter their drug regime so that I can present it to the doctor, make sure they take it, and understand the side effects.
As a doctor, I want to see how the adverse drug effect events change when I make different treatment decisions for a patient.
As a consumer, I want to easily find alternative treatments and understand them.
As a consumer I want to enter basic characteristics (e.g. gender and age) to see how the drug might affect someone like me.
As a nursing mother I want to know which drugs to avoid so that I can have a health pregnancy
As an FDA researcher I want system users to vote on which symptoms they've experienced so that I can understand drug interactions better.
As a senior citizen with multiple health conditions I want to know which medications to avoid so I don't exacerbate my condition.
As a senior citizen I want a clear and easy to read interface so that I can use the application successfully.
As a person who has entered his prescriptions into the app I want a way to set a password so that my personal data is protected.
As a nurse practitioner I want to know the dates when the patient started taking the drug and in what does so that I can give her the right advice.
As a parent of three children I want to have three separate lists for each child so that I can manage their individual information clearly.
As a Doctor or a caregiver, I want to set up a drug regime and share it with a patient so that the patient can understand when to report a side effect and so that we can both understand it.
As a professional advocate, I want people to share their regimes with me, but I want them to be able to unsure this data to me to preserve their privacy if our relationship ends.
As a sufferer of a symptom, I want to understand how likely it is that my symptom is caused by my drug regime.
As a caregiver to a person experiencing a problem, I want to explore what drugs might be causing the problem.
As a researcher, I want to look for unexpected adverse effects when drugs are taken together rather than singly in to identify new drug interactions.
As a caregiver, I want to understand is an adverse effect is likely to be caused by a drug interaction, or is simply a common adverse effect of the drugs taken singly.

cards.desc: This is the "more detail than the list of possible adverse reactions on the medication bottle" story.
cards.name: As a consumer, I want to know if this adverse effect is common or rare, so that I can decide if I need to take action.
As an open-source hacker, I want to be able to use and build upon your system without having to install anything.
As an evaluator at the GSA, I want to see that you can build very light-weight systems quickly.
As an open-source hacker, I want to be able to copy your work and install it easily.
As a young person who mostly uses my phone, I want to use your system in a mobile-friendly way.
As an old person with a lot of problems, I want to know that you understand 508 compliance and are make the site easy for the disabled to use.

As a consumer with an ailment, I want to know how many people had the same ailment, even if they aren't taking the same medicine as me, and I want to know what medicines they are taking (in aggregation), to see what my options are.
As Martha, I want to see mockup ASAP in order to understand what y'all are gibbering about.
As a consumer without a science/stats background I want data to be presented accurately and fairly so that I can make good decisions.
As a doctor I want a graphical representation of the occurrences of side effects.
As a researcher I want to see aggregate counts of what drugs+symptoms are searched for, so I can get more data about potential interactions
As a busy physician in an rural community, I want to be able to compare likely side affects between 2 possible regimes
As a primary care provider in a rural community, I would also like to know the date drugs were approved in case there are newer ones I was not aware of.
small town pharmacists play a huge role in patient care

members.bio: Brandcrafter, hill seeker, and mojito connoisseur.

Been programming since '68. Been online since '75. Been a deadhead since '76. Been a disc golfer since '79. Been free from MIT since '81. Been Broadcatching since '84. Been an EFF member since '90. Been web serving since '93. Been creating OpenPrivacy since '00. Been a dad since '01. Been at CivicActions since '05. Been in Pittsburgh since '07. Been in Orion since '12.

checkItems.name: Coordinate with Martha and define her role
Confirm roles / participation of full team
Get a handle on what "documentation" is and how we want to capture it
Early in the project, spend time with current and prospective users of the service
Use a range of qualitative and quantitative research methods to determine people’s goals, needs, and behaviors; be thoughtful about the time spent
Test prototypes of solutions with real people, in the field if possible
Document the findings about user goals, needs, behaviors, and preferences
Share findings with the team and agency leadership
Create a prioritized list of tasks the user is trying to accomplish, also known as "user stories"
As the digital service is being built, regularly test it with potential users to ensure it meets people’s needs
Understand the different points at which people will interact with the service – both online and in person
Identify pain points in the current way users interact with the service, and prioritize these according to user needs
Design the digital parts of the service so that they are integrated with the offline touch points people use to interact with the service
Develop metrics that will measure how well the service is meeting user needs at each step of the service
Create or use an existing, simple, and flexible design style guide for the service
Use the design style guide consistently for related digital services
Give users clear information about where they are in each step of the process
Follow accessibility best practices to ensure all people can use the service
Provide users with a way to exit and return later to complete the process
Use language that is familiar to the user and easy to understand
Use language and design consistently throughout the service, including online and offline touch points

Ship a functioning “minimum viable product” (MVP) that solves a core user need as soon as possible, no longer than three months from the beginning of the project, using a “beta” or “test” period if needed
Run usability tests frequently to see how well the service works and identify improvements that should be made
Ensure the individuals building the service communicate closely using techniques such as launch meetings, war rooms, daily standups, and team chat tools
Keep delivery teams small and focused; limit organizational layers that separate these teams from the business owners
Release features and improvements multiple times each month
Create a prioritized list of features and bugs, also known as the “feature backlog” and “bug backlog”
Use a source code version control system
Give the entire project team access to the issue tracker and version control system
Use code reviews to ensure quality
Budget includes research, discovery, and prototyping activities
Contract is structured to request frequent deliverables, not multi-month milestones
Contract is structured to hold vendors accountable to deliverables
Contract gives the government delivery team enough flexibility to adjust feature prioritization and delivery schedule as the project evolves
Contract ensures open source solutions are evaluated when technology choices are made
Contract specifies that software and data generated by third parties remains under our control, and can be reused and released to the public as appropriate and in accordance with the law
Contract allows us to use tools, services, and hosting from vendors with a variety of pricing models, including fixed fees and variable models like “pay-for-what-you-use” services
Contract specifies a warranty period where defects uncovered by the public are addressed by the vendor at no additional cost to the government
Contract includes a transition of services period and transition-out plan
A product owner has been identified
All stakeholders agree that the product owner has the authority to assign tasks and make decisions about features and technical implementation details
The product owner has a product management background with technical experience to assess alternatives and weigh tradeoffs
The product owner has a work plan that includes budget estimates and identifies funding sources
The product owner has a strong relationship with the contracting officer
Member(s) of the team have experience building popular, high-traffic digital services
Member(s) of the team have experience designing mobile and web applications
Member(s) of the team have experience using automated testing frameworks
Member(s) of the team have experience with modern development and operations (DevOps) techniques like continuous integration and continuous deployment
Member(s) of the team have experience securing digital services
A Federal contracting officer is on the internal team if a third party will be used for development work
A Federal budget officer is on the internal team or is a partner
The appropriate privacy, civil liberties, and/or legal advisor for the department or agency is a partner
Choose software frameworks that are commonly used by private-sector companies creating similar services
Whenever possible, ensure that software can be deployed on a variety of commodity hardware types
Ensure that each project has clear, understandable instructions for setting up a local development environment, and that team members can be quickly added or removed from projects
Consider open source software solutions at every layer of the stack
Resources are provisioned on demand
Resources scale based on real-time user demand
Resources are provisioned through an API
Resources are available in multiple regions
We only pay for resources we use
Static assets are served through a content delivery network
Application is hosted on commodity hardware
Create automated tests that verify all user-facing functionality
Create unit and integration tests to verify modules and components
Run tests automatically as part of the build process
Perform deployments automatically with deployment scripts, continuous delivery services, or similar techniques
Conduct load and performance tests at regular intervals, including before public launch
Contact the appropriate privacy or legal officer of the department or agency to determine whether a System of Records Notice (SORN), Privacy Impact Assessment, or other review should be conducted
Determine, in consultation with a records officer, what data is collected and why, how it is used or shared, how it is stored and secured, and how long it is kept

Determine, in consultation with a privacy specialist, whether and how users are notified about how personal information is collected and used, including whether a privacy policy is needed and where it should appear, and how users will be notified in the event of a security breach
Consider whether the user should be able to access, delete, or remove their information from the service
“Pre-certify” the hosting infrastructure used for the project using FedRAMP
Use deployment scripts to ensure configuration of production environment remains consistent and controllable
Monitor system-level resource utilization in real time
Monitor system performance in real-time (e.g. response time, latency, throughput, and error rates)
Ensure monitoring can measure median, 95th percentile, and 98th percentile performance
Create automated alerts based on this monitoring
Track concurrent users in real-time, and monitor user behaviors in the aggregate to determine how well the service meets user needs
Publish metrics internally
Publish metrics externally
Use an experimentation tool that supports multivariate testing in production
Offer users a mechanism to report bugs and issues, and be responsive to these reports
Provide datasets to the public, in their entirety, through bulk downloads and APIs (application programming interfaces)
Ensure that data from the service is explicitly in the public domain, and that rights are waived globally via an international public domain dedication, such as the “Creative Commons Zero” waiver
Catalog data in the agency’s enterprise data inventory and add any public datasets to the agency’s public data listing
Ensure that we maintain the rights to all data developed by third parties in a manner that is releasable and reusable at no cost to the public
Ensure that we maintain contractual rights to all custom software developed by third parties in a manner that is publishable and reusable at no cost
When appropriate, create an API for third parties and internal users to interact with the service directly
When appropriate, publish source code of projects or components online
When appropriate, share your development process and progress publicly

card.name: 13. Default to open
13. Default to open
card.desc: When we collaborate in the open and publish our data publicly, we can improve Government together. By building services more openly and publishing open data, we simplify the public’s access to government services and information, allow the public to contribute easily, and enable reuse by entrepreneurs, nonprofits, other agencies, and the public.

card.name: 12. Use data to drive decisions
12. Use data to drive decisions
card.desc: At every stage of a project, we should measure how well our service is working for our users. This includes measuring how well a system performs and how people are interacting with it in real-time. Our teams and agency leadership should carefully watch these metrics to find issues and identify which bug fixes and improvements should be prioritized. Along with monitoring tools, a feedback mechanism should be in place for people to report issues directly.

card.name: 11. Manage security and privacy through reusable processes
11. Manage security and privacy through reusable processes
card.desc: Our digital services have to protect sensitive information and keep systems secure. This is typically a process of continuous review and improvement which should be built into the development and maintenance of the service. At the start of designing a new service or feature, the team lead should engage the appropriate privacy, security, and legal officer(s) to discuss the type of information collected, how it should be secured, how long it is kept, and how it may be used and shared. The sustained engagement of a privacy specialist helps ensure that personal data is properly managed. In addition, a key process to building a secure service is comprehensively testing and certifying the components in each layer of the technology stack for security vulnerabilities, and then to re-use these same pre-certified components for multiple services.The following checklist provides a starting point, but teams should work closely with their privacy specialist and security engineer to meet the needs of the specific service.

card.name: 10. Automate testing and deployments
10. Automate testing and deployments
card.desc: Today, developers write automated scripts that can verify thousands of scenarios in minutes and then deploy updated code into production environments multiple times a day. They use automated performance tests which simulate surges in traffic to identify performance bottlenecks. While manual tests and quality assurance are still necessary, automated tests provide consistent and reliable protection against unintentional regressions, and make it possible for developers to confidently release frequent updates to the service.

card.name: 9. Deploy in a flexible hosting environment
9. Deploy in a flexible hosting environment
card.desc: Our services should be deployed on flexible infrastructure, where resources can be provisioned in real-time to meet spikes traffic and user demand. Our digital services are crippled when we host them in data centers that market themselves as “cloud hosting” but require us to manage and maintain hardware directly. This outdated practice wastes time, weakens our disaster recovery plans, and results in significantly higher costs.

card.name: 8. Choose a modern technology stack
8. Choose a modern technology stack
card.desc: The technology decisions we make need to enable development teams to work efficiently and enable services to scale easily and cost-effectively. Our choices for hosting infrastructure, databases, software frameworks, programming languages and the rest of the technology stack should seek to avoid vendor lock-in and match what successful modern consumer and enterprise software companies would choose today. In particular, digital services teams should consider using open source, cloud-based, and commodity solutions across the technology stack, because of their widespread adoption and support by successful consumer and enterprise technology companies in the private sector.

card.name: 7. Bring in experienced teams
7. Bring in experienced teams
card.desc: We need talented people working in government who have experience creating modern digital services. This includes bringing in seasoned product managers, engineers, and designers. When outside help is needed, our teams should work with contracting officers who understand how to evaluate third-party technical competency so our teams can be paired with contractors who are good at both building and delivering effective digital services. The makeup and experience requirements of the team will vary depending on the scope of the project.

card.name: 6. Assign one leader and hold that person accountable
6. Assign one leader and hold that person accountable
card.desc: There must be a single product owner who has the authority and responsibility to assign tasks and work elements; make business, product, and technical decisions; and be accountable for the success or failure of the overall service. This product owner is ultimately responsible for how well the service meets needs of its users, which is how a service should be evaluated. The product owner is responsible for ensuring that features are built and managing the feature and bug backlogs.

To improve our chances of success when contracting out development work, we need to work with experienced budgeting and contracting officers. In cases where we use third parties to help build a service, a well-defined contract can facilitate good development practices like conducting a research and prototyping phase, refining product requirements as the service is built, evaluating open source alternatives, ensuring frequent delivery milestones, and allowing the flexibility to purchase cloud computing resources.

The TechFAR Handbook provides a detailed explanation of the flexibilities in the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) that can help agencies implement this play.

data.text:
Example result set showing multiple medications taken by user:

card.name: How can we correlate a drug with the number of times it is likely to be used? Can we find out that Tylenol is used 100M times with 1K serious affects, but something else is used 10K times with 10 serious effects, which is actually 10 times more likely to cause an effect?

data.text: @ethant1 @ethant1 I think Ron added this card.   Nonetheless I think this page: https://open.fda.gov/api/reference/#query-syntax partially describes the fields

card.name: Personnel, roles, schedules
Github
As Martha, I want to see mockup ASAP in order to understand what y'all are gibbering about.

As a consumer with an ailment, I want to know how many people had the same ailment, even if they aren't taking the same medicine as me, and I want to know what medicines they are taking (in aggregation), to see what my options are.
As an old person with a lot of problems, I want to know that you understand 508 compliance and are make the site easy for the disabled to use.
As a young person who mostly uses my phone, I want to use your system in a mobile-friendly way.
As a consumer, I want to enter my medicines and my affects and see how often others have experienced them to give me peace of mind.
As a consumer, I want to be able to easily enter my drug regime with typeahead based on multiple names to get the benefits of the system.
How can we see all the fields? Seems like what's available will influence what we may do.

data.text: @readrobert Are you asking how do we see all possible items that can be returned in the fda JSON array, or something else?

card.name: As a parent of three children I want to have three separate lists for each child so that I can manage their individual information clearly.

How can we correlate a drug with the number of times it is likely to be used? Can we find out that Tylenol is used 100M times with 1K serious affects, but something else is used 10K times with 10 serious effects, which is actually 10 times more likely to cause an effect?
As a nurse practitioner I want to know the dates when the patient started taking the drug and in what does so that I can give her the right advice.
As a person who has entered his prescriptions into the app I want a way to set a password so that my personal data is protected.
As an evaluator at the GSA, I want to see that you can build very light-weight systems quickly.
As a senior citizen I want a clear and easy to read interface so that I can use the application successfully.
As an open-source hacker, I want to be able to copy your work and install it easily.
As an open-source hacker, I want to be able to use and build upon your system without having to install anything.
As a senior citizen with multiple health conditions I want to know which medications to avoid so I don't exacerbate my condition.

As a person who is taking multiple drugs and is having an adverse affect, I would like to see a visualization of the adverse events associated with my drug regime to understand and perhaps decrease them.

old.name: As a person who is having multiple drugs and is having an adverse affect, I would like to see a visualization of the adverse events associated with my drug regime to understand and perhaps decrease them.

card.name: As a caregiver to a person experiencing a problem, I want to explore what drugs might be causing the problem.
As a sufferer of a symptom, I want to understand how likely it is that my symptom is caused by my drug regime.
As an FDA researcher I want system users to vote on which symptoms they've experienced so that I can understand drug interactions better.
As a researcher, I want to look for unexpected adverse effects when drugs are taken together rather than singly in to identify new drug interactions.
As a nursing mother I want to know which drugs to avoid so that I can have a health pregnancy
As a caregiver, I want to understand is an adverse effect is likely to be caused by a drug interaction, or is simply a common adverse effect of the drugs taken singly.
As a consumer, I want to know if this adverse effect is common or rare, so that I can decide if I need to take action.
card.desc: This is the "more detail than the list of possible adverse reactions on the medication bottle" story.

card.name: As a professional advocate, I want people to share their regimes with me, but I want them to be able to unsure this data to me to preserve their privacy if our relationship ends.
As a Doctor or a caregiver, I want to set up a drug regime and share it with a patient so that the patient can understand when to report a side effect and so that we can both understand it.
As a consumer I want to enter basic characteristics (e.g. gender and age) to see how the drug might affect someone like me.
As a consumer, I want to know if this adverse effect is common or rare, so that I can decide if I need to take action.
As a consumer, I want to easily find alternative treatments and understand them.
As a doctor, I want to see how the adverse drug effect events change when I make different treatment decisions for a patient.
As a caregiver, I want my parent to enter their drug regime so that I can present it to the doctor, make sure they take it, and understand the side effects.
As a consumer, I want to test your system without giving any personal information, and then later associate my searches with my identity if I choose to.
As a consumer, I want to understand the benefits that your system offers to that i can decide whether or not to use it.
As a consumer, I want to enter my ailments in the language of the database so that I can easily get the benefits of the system.
As a consumer, I want to be able to easily enter my drug regime with typeahead based on multiple names to get the benefits of the system.

old.name: As a consumer, I want to be able to easily enter my drug regime with typeahead based on multiple names.

card.name: As a consumer, I want to be able to easily enter my drug regime with typeahead based on multiple names.
As a consumer, I want to store and consider multiple drug regimes to be able to compare them.
As a consumer, I want to enter my medicines and my affects and see how often others have experienced them to give me peace of mind.

As a caregiver, I am caring for someone and I know what drugs they take, but they are having side effects and I want to understand how they may be related to the drugs they are taking and consider the impact of changes to there regime.

As a person who is having multiple drugs and is having an adverse affect, I would like to see a visualization of the adverse events associated with my drug regime to understand and perhaps decrease them.

old.name: As a person who is having multiple drugs and is having an adverse affect, I would like to see a visualization of the adverse events associated with my drug regime.

data.text:
some general techniques INPO:
- task analysis- how does someone do what they do?
- contextual inquiry- what environmental/contextual factors affect use?
- card sort - how do people sort and organize stuff?
- interviews/surveys
- personae

card.name: Build a visual map of all drug events, and be able to replay them across time. Show a blinking map of your city to show the events.

I still don't quite know how one discovers the various vocablulaires in the system. I think we as a team need to know how to get the list of all known adverse events, and the list of all known drugs, etc.
look-ahead type search, where I start typing "hyper..." and it automatically starts showing me medications prescribed for hypertension and hyperactivity.  Gogglize the database.
User takes a picture with their mobile phone (or enters pill identifying information) to quickly retrieve the adverse effects.

data.text: I like this idea (a lot) @pava , I just don't know what technology we would use to do this.

card.name: Enter symptom, and medications taking, to show which medication are known to cause symptom.

data.text: This one seems pretty doable to me. Patient drug interactions are pretty well documented, and easy to grab from the fda json stream. https://open.fda.gov/drug/event/reference/ I can see us creating something nifty with chart.js (or another js lib) for this app.

card.name: An app that a doctor (or patient) could use prior to prescribing multiple drugs to validate if there are adverse effects with each other.
User takes a picture with their mobile phone (or enters pill identifying information) to quickly retrieve the adverse effects.
Advocate of natural healing seeking to emphasize danger of prescribed drugs over natural remedies.
Justice advocate seeking to demonstrate that most drug testing being done on white males leads to more side effects for women and minority genetic groups.
Walled-garden community in which only professionals can play --- we can make our github repo workable for that purpose.  Using Drupal and virtualization should be possible.
An advanced practice nurse/prescriber specialty family practice and clinical education.  I use this site to determine clearance for medical devices (CLIA waived), product safety, etc.

Uses FDA data
card.desc:
Rob: Adverse drug events database, largest and most recently made available. For 20 years FDA has recorded every adverse reaction to a drug. Valuable to many people - drug producers (pro vs con), healthcare advocates (con vs pro), researchers (discovering interactions).

API data structure is moderately complex. Not very approachable for consumers. Developed by presidential IT fellow.

JSON based API - example:
Date: ...
Person (no name)
Outcome:
Event:
Where:
Drug:

Some fields are structured, some are free text. Some other tables to detail/embellish standardized fields (Drugs etc).

card.name: Iterative approach
Uses FDA data
card.desc:
Rob: Adverse drug events database, largest and most recently made available. For 20 years FDA has recorded every adverse reaction to a drug. Valuable to many people - drug producers (pro vs con), healthcare advocates (con vs pro), researchers (discovering interactions).

API data structure is moderately complex. Not very approachable for consumers. Developed by presidential IT fellow.

card.name: Perform usability tests with people
Perform usability tests with "people"
Uses style guide
card.desc: created or used a design style guide and/or a pattern library

card.name: Uses style guide
3 Human centered design techniques
Human centered design
card.desc: used at least three "human-centered design" techniques or tools

card.name: Human centered design
Include "people" in the process
card.desc: understand what people need, by including people in the prototype development and design process

card.name: Include "people" in the process
Multidisciplinary Team
card.desc: assembled a multidisciplinary and collaborative team including a minimum of 5 labor categories from the Development Pool labor categories to design and develop the prototype

card.name: Multidisciplinary Team
Uses FDA data
One leader
card.desc: assigned one leader, gave that person authority and responsibility, and held that person accountable for the quality of the prototype submitted

card.name: Clearly valuable to consumers (either doctors or consumers), ideally have an easy step-through or video showing how to use.
One leader
used at least five modern and open-source technologies, regardless of architectural layer (frontend, backend etc)
Be cool
Be useful to FDA data users
